attributes.title: New insights into the adults drinking cultures across Europe

q1.value: New insights into adults drinking culture across Europe

q3.value: In recent decades, several publications have described a growing homogenisation of drinking habits in Europe, indicating that formerly widespread characterisations of drinking cultures are no longer suitable to describe drinking habits. In addition, critique was expressed that drinking culture research focused mainly on national differences in alcohol use, while neglecting that drinking cultures may also vary within a society (Savic, Room, Mugavin, Pennay, & Livingston, 2016). Therefore, we will (1) update the current literature as we will determine adult drinking cultures using data from more than a dozen European countries collected between 2015 and 2016, and (2) provide new insights into European drinking cultures using a model-based probabilistic approach that analyses key drinking variables at the individual-level.

q4.value:
First hypothesis: In the light of an increased homogenisation of alcohol consumption in Europe, we hypothesised that drinking cultures are not country-specific, but that each drinking culture will be present in each country. 

Second hypothesis: Given the growing popularity of beer consumption in traditionally wine- and spirits-drinking societies, we hypothesised that the beverage preference will only marginally contribute to the differentiation of drinking cultures.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Cross-sectional analysis of general population survey data.

q9.value: Randomised sampling procedures were applied in all countries to select a representative general population sample.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value: Data were used from the Standardised European Alcohol Survey from 2015/2016 which provided comprehensive data on alcohol epidemiology of a total number of 33,237 adult individuals (18 to 65 years of age) from 19 European countries and one autonomous community.

q13.value: The sample size was about 1,500 respondents in each country, but varied from less than 1,000 in Iceland to over 3,000 in Austria.

question.value: Drinking cultures are determined using latent class analyses.

(1) Determining drinking cultures: Latent class analyses will be used to determine drinking cultures. The drinking variables (described above) will be included as indicator variables and fitted according to their individual distributions (ad-hoc analyses using histograms). Models will be adjusted for the respondents' country; survey weights will be applied to account for sampling bias. To determine the number of latent classes, multiple models including two, three, four and five latent classes will be compared taken into account goodness-of-fit statistics (AIC/BIC) and substantive considerations. 
(2) Comparing drinking cultures across countries: Individual class endorsement probabilities will be compared across countries using fractional response regression analyses. For each drinking class, two separate regression models will be performed: a first set of regression models that includes supranational region as independent variable and a second set that takes into account sociodemographics (gender, age, educational achievement), the size of place of residence and the individual harm. In the first set of regression models, gender, age and educational achievement will be included as control variables. Survey weights will be applied. 

(3) Sensitivity analyses: LCA and regression analyses will be repeated stratified by gender.

q21.value:
Number of latent classes will be determined using Bayesian information criterion (BIC) and Akaike information criterion (AIC) as well as substantive considerations (such as plausibility). 
Regression analyses: Control variables will be considered if adjustment accounted for a change of more than 10% in the beta coefficients of the predictors. P-values will be corrected using Bonferroni corrections if multiple regression analyses were run comparing the same population.

q23.value: Respondents with missing data for any of the required drinking variables, gender or age will be excluded from all analyses.

q25.value: Savic, M., Room, R., Mugavin, J., Pennay, A., & Livingston, M. (2016). Defining “drinking culture”: A critical review of its meaning and connotation in social research on alcohol problems. Drugs: Education Prevention and Policy, 23(4), 270–282. https://doi.org/10.3109/09687637.2016.1153602

item1.value: Past research (Cimpian & Scott, 2012) indicates that children expect generic knowledge (e.g. "Hedgehogs eat hexapods") to be more widely shared than specific knowledge ("Last night, this hedgehog ate hexapods") as measured by whether they think their mom would know the information.

item2.value: Replicating this effect will confirm the original findings and the efficacy of the basic procedure, allowing me to build off the original findings by clarifying WHY children expect generic knowledge to be especially widely shared.

item27.value: In addition to the analysis performed in the original study, we will be working to develop an exploratory generative model to inform similar efforts in future projects.

attributes.title: The Role of Working Memory Capacity in Analytic and Multiply-Constrained Problem Solving in Demanding Situations

summary.value: This registration is for a completed project by which we are making the materials and data openly available. This project sought to examine whether cognitive load affected problem solving ability. Specifically, when the participant was given environmental support did they solve more algebra and compound remote associate problems.

attributes.title: Intentions from faces
attributes.description: In this study, we investigate whether people will use a target agent's facial structure when making predictions about their intentions to act morally or immorally
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

dataCollectionDates.value: Data collection is estimated to begin and end between January 24-31, 2020.

question2a.value:
1. Face type (trustworthy, neutral, untrustworthy), within subjects
2. Trial type (intentional vs. unintentional), within-subjects
Relationship between 1 and; 2: orthogonal.

question10b.value:
After reviewing the information sheet, participants will be presented with a link to an external survey, hosted by Qualtrics. Participants will then be given instructions for how to complete the survey. They will then read 60 short vignettes, each paired with a computer-generated image of a male face. Face stimuli were selected from a set of 100 distinct facial identities that were randomly generated using the program FaceGen (https://facegen.com/). Each facial identity was manipulated to create three distinct face images: maximally trustworthy, untrustworthy, and neutral. All facial stimuli provided by Alexander Todorov. See Oosterhof, N. N., & Todorov, A. (2008). The functional basis of face evaluation. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the USA, 105, 11087-11092.
For each vignette, participants will make a forced-choice prediction about the outcome, based on two response options (positive or negative). Thirty of these vignettes will be intentional trials in which the person depicted is faced with a moral choice. The response options for experimental trials will always include one “positive intention” (in which the person makes a selfless, moral choice), and one “negative intention” (in which the person makes a selfish, immoral choice). The participants will also see additional 30 unintentional control vignettes, which will feature vignettes in which participants must make predictions about whether positive or negative outcomes outside of the agent's control will befall them.  One other vignette will be an attention check.
After completing the 60 prediction questions, participants will be asked to enter their age in years, and indicate whether they identify as male, female, or non-binary. They will also be asked to write what they thought the hypothesis of the study was. They will then be provided with a uniquely identifying survey code, which they will then enter into the Amazon Mechanical Turk interface.

Vignettes: The 30 moral intention vignettes have selected on the basis of an initial norming study. The 30 unintentional control vignettes describing positive and negative outcomes were selected on the basis of a separate initial norming study. Face identities have been randomly assigned to each vignette. 

Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the three survey versions in which the trustworthiness of each facial identity assigned to each vignette and the right-left position of the negative moral intention/outcome response and the will be counterbalanced across participants.

question4b.value: In accordance with research on MTurk data quality, participants who meet our inclusion criteria will have at least a 95% HIT approval rating on MTurk, and have completed at least 100 HITs (Peer, Vosgerau, and Acquisti, 2014). Participants must be located in the United States.

question5b.value: Participants will be recruited using Amazon’s Mechanical Turk Platform, https://www.mturk.com/, and will complete an online survey made with Qualtrics.

question6b.value: To facilitate a direct comparison with the results from study 1, we aim to collect data from at least 209 participants.

question7b.value: We will continue collecting data until we reach our planned sample size of 209 participants after exclusions.

question1a.value:
H1: We predict that we will replicate the key finding of Study 1:  
"Participants were more likely to attribute a negative moral intention to characters with neutral facial features relative to those possessing trustworthy facial features (Mtrustworthy = .43, Mneutral = .51, z = 4.75, p < .001) and characters possessing untrustworthy features relative to those possessing either trustworthy or neutral features (Muntrustworthy = .61, z = 7.78, p < .001 and z = 5.80, p < .001 respectively). Crucially, participants’ responses were biased toward attributing positive moral intentions to characters with trustworthy facial features (z = 4.06, p < .001) and negative moral intentions to characters with untrustworthy features (z = 5.58, p < .001). Participants’ attributions toward neutral faces were not biased one way or the other (z = .10, p = .691)."
H2: If the valence-matching explanation of this previous finding is correct, and participants were simply mapping positive faces onto positive outcomes and negative faces onto negative outcomes, rather than making inferences about the characters' underlying intentions based on their facial features, then we should expect a similar effect of face type on negative/positive responses  as observed in study 1 in both the intentional and unintentional trials. If however the intentions-based account is correct, then we should expect to replicate the effect of face type observed in study 1 in the intentional trials only.

question2a.value:
A further prediction of the intention-attribution hypothesis is that we might observe an interaction between Face Type and Trial Type, such that the effect of face type on predicted outcomes is significantly different in intentional and unintentional trials. The shape of this interaction could however take many forms, however. 
1. It could be that there is no effect of face-type in unintentional trials. This would suggest that participants do not view facial trustworthiness as relevant to questions about whether good or bad things happen to an agent. This would be fairly clear evidence against the valence-matching hypothesis.
2. It could also be that the effect of face type on outcomes in unintentional trials is similar in shape to the effect of that we expect to observe in intentional trials (if study 1's results are replicated), albeit significantly weaker. This would suggest that valence-matching contributed to the effects observed in study 1, but that intention-tracking affected outcome choices over and above valence-matching. 
3. We might also observe a significant effect of face-type in the unintentional conditions, albeit with a shape that is distinct from (or even the inverse of) the effect observed in study 1 (e.g. participants might be more likely to predict that positive outcomes will befall people with untrustworthy or neutral faces, and that negative outcomes will befall people with trustworthy faces). Such an interaction effect would count as evidence against the valence-matching explanation of the findings in study 1.

question3a.value:
Our manipulation of facial trustworthiness is based on pre-validated stimuli provided by Alexander Todorov. See Oosterhof, N. N., & Todorov, A. (2008). The functional basis of face evaluation. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the USA, 105, 11087-11092.

In this study, we introduced a new variable: trial type (intentional vs. unintentional). For several reasons, a manipulation check is not appropriate for a study with this design.
1. In intentional vignettes, response options clearly mention the character's intentions, and refer to specific actions that the character might take. In unintentional vignettes, outcomes are always the product of forces beyond the character's control, and the character's intentions are never mentioned. The relevance of intentions in the different trials is very clear. 
2. Trial type is manipulated within-subjects. All participants will see both types of trial.
3. To ensure that intentional and unintentional trials are otherwise well-matched, test trials were selected via a norming procedure in two separate pilot studies (one for intentional vignettes and one of unintentional vignettes). Vignettes were presented to MTurkers in the absence of facial trustworthiness information, and vignettes that strong positive or negative response biases were eliminated. To be included in the study, vignettes had to have a mean response score of 0 (i.e. no response bias towards negative or positive outcomes).

question5a.value:
Rationale:
Human beings make rapid social judgments about how trustworthy a person is on the basis of their facial appearance (Bar, Neta, & Linz, 2006; Todorov, 2013; Todorov, Said, Engell, & Oosterhof, 2008). These “first impressions” have been shown to have significant effects on subsequent behavior, including decisions about whom to trust in an economic game and which politician one will vote for in an election (Falvello, Vinson, Ferrari, & Todorov, 2015; Olivola & Todorov, 2010). Inferences about trustworthiness of a face with a neutral expression appear to be related to mechanisms for detecting emotional facial expressions (more trustworthy faces tend to appear more happy, while more untrustworthy faces tend to appear more angry); it has thus been suggested that face-based judgments of trustworthiness thus serve the function of anticipating people’s behavioral intentions (Ames, Fiske, & Todorov, 2011; Todorov, 2008; Westra, 2017). This idea has very significant implications for our understanding of other socio-cognitive processes that involve the attribution of intentions, especially moral cognition (Greene et al., 2009; Leslie, Knobe, & Cohen, 2006): it suggests that we use people’s faces to inform our judgments about their moral behavior. However, this hypothesis has not been directly tested, and it is unclear whether the effects of facial trustworthiness on social behavior reflect substantive predictions about intentions, or simple affective preferences.
The primary aim of this study is to examine how social judgments based on facial appearance affect our expectations about people’s moral decision-making. Specifically, we will investigate whether participants are inclined to expect that a person with a “trustworthy” face will make moral choices, and that of a person with an “untrustworthy” face will make immoral choice. To do this, we will present participants with vignettes paired with computer-generated images of male faces created with the program FaceGen (https://facegen.com/) that have been previously shown to elicit strong judgments of trustworthiness (Oosterhof & Todorov, 2008). Trustworthy, untrustworthy, and neutral faces will be randomly paired with vignettes in which an agent is faced with a moral decision, and participants will be asked to attribute positive or negative moral intentions to them. We expect to find a main effect of facial trustworthiness on moral intention attributions.
In Study 1, we found that facial appearance did indeed have a significant effect on whether participants attributed positive or negative moral intentions to an agent: the more untrustworthy a face appeared, the moral likely participants were to judge that the protagonist in the vignette had immoral intentions. 
However, it is possible that participants in this earlier study were simply associating trustworthy faces with positive outcomes and untrustworthy faces with negative outcomes. To control for this alternative “valence-matching” hypothesis and to replicate our original results, the current study will introduce a new set of 30 "unintentional" control vignettes (replacing the 30 distractor vignettes from the survey in study 1), in which participants are asked to make predictions about whether a positive or negative event will befall the protagonist. If the “valence-matching” hypothesis is correct, we should expect to find comparable effects of facial trustworthiness in both the intentional and unintentional control trials; however, if our original hypothesis is correct, we should expect to find a significant effect of facial trustworthiness in our moral intention trials, but not in our control trials. 


References:
Ames, D. L., Fiske, S. T., & Todorov, A. (2011). Impression formation: A focus on others’ intents. The Oxford handbook of social neuroscience. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
Bar, M., Neta, M., & Linz, H. (2006). Very first impressions. Emotion, 6(2), 269–278.
Berinsky, A. J., Huber, G. A., & Lenz, G. S. (2012). Evaluating Online Labor Markets for Experimental Research: Amazon.com’s Mechanical Turk. Political Analysis, 20, 351–368.
Falvello, V., Vinson, M., Ferrari, C., & Todorov, A. (2015). The Robustness of Learning about the Trustworthiness of Other People. Social Cognition, 33(5), 368–386.
Greene, J. D., Cushman, F. A., Stewart, L. E., Lowenberg, K., Nystrom, L. E., & Cohen, J. D. (2009). Pushing moral buttons: the interaction between personal force and intention in moral judgment. Cognition, 111(3), 364–71.
Lease, M., Hullman, J., Bigham, J. P., Bernstein, M. S., Kim, J., Lasecki, W., … Miller, R. C. (2013). Mechanical Turk is Not Anonymous. SSRN Electronic Journal.
Leslie, A. M., Knobe, J., & Cohen, A. (2006). Acting intentionally and the side-effect effect. Psychological Science, 17(5), 421–7.
Olivola, C. Y., & Todorov, A. (2010). Elected in 100 milliseconds: Appearance-Based Trait Inferences and Voting. Journal of Nonverbal Behavior, 34(2), 83–110.
Oosterhof, N. N., & Todorov, A. (2008). The functional basis of face evaluation. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America, 105(32), 11087–92.
Peer, E., Vosgerau, J., & Acquisti, A. (2014). Reputation as a sufficient condition for data quality on Amazon Mechanical Turk. Behavior Research Methods, 46(4), 1023–1031.
Todorov, A. (2008). Evaluating faces on trustworthiness: An extension of systems for recognition of emotions signaling approach/avoidance behaviors. Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences.
Todorov, A. (2013). Making up your mind after 100-ms exposure to face. Psychological Science, 17(7), 592–598.
Todorov, A., Said, C. P., Engell, A. D., & Oosterhof, N. N. (2008). Understanding evaluation of faces on social dimensions. Trends in Cognitive Sciences, 12(12), 455–460.
Westra, E. (2017). Character and theory of mind: an integrative approach. Philosophical Studies.

question1c.value: For each question, participants are asked to make a forced choice between two responses. On trials describing a moral choice, these responses describe either a Trustworthy intention = 1 or Untrustworthy intention = -1. On all other trials these responses describe either a Positive Outcome = 1 or Negative Outcome = -1. Our final data will retain the trial-level data for all participants but will permit of summary statistics such as assessing the proportion of trials that a single (or all) participant selected each response type. A mean proportion of = is equal to chance responding

question2c.value: Our main analyses will be conducted over participants’ responses on each trial. We will utilize a Generalized Linear Mixed Model (GLMM) fit by maximum likelihood with Laplace approximation and a binomial link function to determine the fixed effects of Face Type (Trustworthy, Neutral, Untrustworthy), Vignette Group (6 levels determined by Experiment 1 and Experiment 2’s norming study), Trial Type (Moral Choice, Unintentional), and Answer Side (Left or Right) on participants’ dichotomous judgments on each trial. We will also assess for an interaction between Face Type and Vignette Group to determine if our selection and group of vignettes influenced participants’ responses. Crucially, we will also assess for a potential interaction between Face Type and Trial Type. The overall significance of each predictor will be assessed using Type II Wald chi-square tests. Overall, this statistical approach accounts for the correlated nature of participants’ responses across trials and our model will include random intercept terms identifying individual subjects (n = 209). In determine the best model of our day we may also choose to include random intercepts identifying each Item Number (n = 60).  These analyses will be implemented in R (R Core Team, 2018) and at the time of writing, we plan to utilizing the glmer() function in the lme4 package (Bates, Maechler, Bolker, & Walker, 2015) and the Anova() function in the car package (Fox & Weisberg, 2011) respectively.

question3c.value:
Outcome (negative/positive): DV
Trial type (intentional/unintentional): IV
Face type (trustworthy/untrustworthy/neutral):IV

To ensure that intentional and unintentional trials are otherwise well-matched, test trials were selected via a norming procedure in two separate pilot studies (one for intentional vignettes and one of unintentional vignettes). Vignettes were presented to MTurkers in the absence of facial trustworthiness information, and vignettes that strong positive or negative response biases were eliminated. To be included in the study, vignettes had to have a mean response score of 0 (i.e. no response bias towards negative or positive outcomes).
registration_responses.recommended-hypothesis.question5a:
Rationale:
Human beings make rapid social judgments about how trustworthy a person is on the basis of their facial appearance (Bar, Neta, & Linz, 2006; Todorov, 2013; Todorov, Said, Engell, & Oosterhof, 2008). These “first impressions” have been shown to have significant effects on subsequent behavior, including decisions about whom to trust in an economic game and which politician one will vote for in an election (Falvello, Vinson, Ferrari, & Todorov, 2015; Olivola & Todorov, 2010). Inferences about trustworthiness of a face with a neutral expression appear to be related to mechanisms for detecting emotional facial expressions (more trustworthy faces tend to appear more happy, while more untrustworthy faces tend to appear more angry); it has thus been suggested that face-based judgments of trustworthiness thus serve the function of anticipating people’s behavioral intentions (Ames, Fiske, & Todorov, 2011; Todorov, 2008; Westra, 2017). This idea has very significant implications for our understanding of other socio-cognitive processes that involve the attribution of intentions, especially moral cognition (Greene et al., 2009; Leslie, Knobe, & Cohen, 2006): it suggests that we use people’s faces to inform our judgments about their moral behavior. However, this hypothesis has not been directly tested, and it is unclear whether the effects of facial trustworthiness on social behavior reflect substantive predictions about intentions, or simple affective preferences.
The primary aim of this study is to examine how social judgments based on facial appearance affect our expectations about people’s moral decision-making. Specifically, we will investigate whether participants are inclined to expect that a person with a “trustworthy” face will make moral choices, and that of a person with an “untrustworthy” face will make immoral choice. To do this, we will present participants with vignettes paired with computer-generated images of male faces created with the program FaceGen (https://facegen.com/) that have been previously shown to elicit strong judgments of trustworthiness (Oosterhof & Todorov, 2008). Trustworthy, untrustworthy, and neutral faces will be randomly paired with vignettes in which an agent is faced with a moral decision, and participants will be asked to attribute positive or negative moral intentions to them. We expect to find a main effect of facial trustworthiness on moral intention attributions.
In Study 1, we found that facial appearance did indeed have a significant effect on whether participants attributed positive or negative moral intentions to an agent: the more untrustworthy a face appeared, the moral likely participants were to judge that the protagonist in the vignette had immoral intentions. 
However, it is possible that participants in this earlier study were simply associating trustworthy faces with positive outcomes and untrustworthy faces with negative outcomes. To control for this alternative “valence-matching” hypothesis and to replicate our original results, the current study will introduce a new set of 30 "unintentional" control vignettes (replacing the 30 distractor vignettes from the survey in study 1), in which participants are asked to make predictions about whether a positive or negative event will befall the protagonist. If the “valence-matching” hypothesis is correct, we should expect to find comparable effects of facial trustworthiness in both the intentional and unintentional control trials; however, if our original hypothesis is correct, we should expect to find a significant effect of facial trustworthiness in our moral intention trials, but not in our control trials. 


References:
Ames, D. L., Fiske, S. T., & Todorov, A. (2011). Impression formation: A focus on others’ intents. The Oxford handbook of social neuroscience. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
Bar, M., Neta, M., & Linz, H. (2006). Very first impressions. Emotion, 6(2), 269–278.
Berinsky, A. J., Huber, G. A., & Lenz, G. S. (2012). Evaluating Online Labor Markets for Experimental Research: Amazon.com’s Mechanical Turk. Political Analysis, 20, 351–368.
Falvello, V., Vinson, M., Ferrari, C., & Todorov, A. (2015). The Robustness of Learning about the Trustworthiness of Other People. Social Cognition, 33(5), 368–386.
Greene, J. D., Cushman, F. A., Stewart, L. E., Lowenberg, K., Nystrom, L. E., & Cohen, J. D. (2009). Pushing moral buttons: the interaction between personal force and intention in moral judgment. Cognition, 111(3), 364–71.
Lease, M., Hullman, J., Bigham, J. P., Bernstein, M. S., Kim, J., Lasecki, W., … Miller, R. C. (2013). Mechanical Turk is Not Anonymous. SSRN Electronic Journal.
Leslie, A. M., Knobe, J., & Cohen, A. (2006). Acting intentionally and the side-effect effect. Psychological Science, 17(5), 421–7.
Olivola, C. Y., & Todorov, A. (2010). Elected in 100 milliseconds: Appearance-Based Trait Inferences and Voting. Journal of Nonverbal Behavior, 34(2), 83–110.
Oosterhof, N. N., & Todorov, A. (2008). The functional basis of face evaluation. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America, 105(32), 11087–92.
Peer, E., Vosgerau, J., & Acquisti, A. (2014). Reputation as a sufficient condition for data quality on Amazon Mechanical Turk. Behavior Research Methods, 46(4), 1023–1031.

registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
After reviewing the information sheet, participants will be presented with a link to an external survey, hosted by Qualtrics. Participants will then be given instructions for how to complete the survey. They will then read 60 short vignettes, each paired with a computer-generated image of a male face. Face stimuli were selected from a set of 100 distinct facial identities that were randomly generated using the program FaceGen (https://facegen.com/). Each facial identity was manipulated to create three distinct face images: maximally trustworthy, untrustworthy, and neutral. All facial stimuli provided by Alexander Todorov. See Oosterhof, N. N., & Todorov, A. (2008). The functional basis of face evaluation. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the USA, 105, 11087-11092.
For each vignette, participants will make a forced-choice prediction about the outcome, based on two response options (positive or negative). Thirty of these vignettes will be intentional trials in which the person depicted is faced with a moral choice. The response options for experimental trials will always include one “positive intention” (in which the person makes a selfless, moral choice), and one “negative intention” (in which the person makes a selfish, immoral choice). The participants will also see additional 30 unintentional control vignettes, which will feature vignettes in which participants must make predictions about whether positive or negative outcomes outside of the agent's control will befall them.  One other vignette will be an attention check.
After completing the 60 prediction questions, participants will be asked to enter their age in years, and indicate whether they identify as male, female, or non-binary. They will also be asked to write what they thought the hypothesis of the study was. They will then be provided with a uniquely identifying survey code, which they will then enter into the Amazon Mechanical Turk interface.

Vignettes: The 30 moral intention vignettes have selected on the basis of an initial norming study. The 30 unintentional control vignettes describing positive and negative outcomes were selected on the basis of a separate initial norming study. Face identities have been randomly assigned to each vignette. 

Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the three survey versions in which the trustworthiness of each facial identity assigned to each vignette and the right-left position of the negative moral intention/outcome response and the will be counterbalanced across participants.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi: For each question, participants are asked to make a forced choice between two responses. On trials describing a moral choice, these responses describe either a Trustworthy intention = 1 or Untrustworthy intention = -1. On all other trials these responses describe either a Positive Outcome = 1 or Negative Outcome = -1. Our final data will retain the trial-level data for all participants but will permit of summary statistics such as assessing the proportion of trials that a single (or all) participant selected each response type. A mean proportion of = is equal to chance responding

Our main analyses will be conducted over participants’ responses on each trial. We will utilize a Generalized Linear Mixed Model (GLMM) fit by maximum likelihood with Laplace approximation and a binomial link function to determine the fixed effects of Face Type (Trustworthy, Neutral, Untrustworthy), Vignette Group (6 levels determined by Experiment 1 and Experiment 2’s norming study), Trial Type (Moral Choice, Unintentional), and Answer Side (Left or Right) on participants’ dichotomous judgments on each trial. We will also assess for an interaction between Face Type and Vignette Group to determine if our selection and group of vignettes influenced participants’ responses. Crucially, we will also assess for a potential interaction between Face Type and Trial Type. The overall significance of each predictor will be assessed using Type II Wald chi-square tests. Overall, this statistical approach accounts for the correlated nature of participants’ responses across trials and our model will include random intercept terms identifying individual subjects (n = 209). In determine the best model of our day we may also choose to include random intercepts identifying each Item Number (n = 60).  These analyses will be implemented in R (R Core Team, 2018) and at the time of writing, we plan to utilizing the glmer() function in the lme4 package (Bates, Maechler, Bolker, & Walker, 2015) and the Anova() function in the car package (Fox & Weisberg, 2011) respectively.

Outcome (negative/positive): DV
Trial type (intentional/unintentional): IV
Face type (trustworthy/untrustworthy/neutral):IV
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: In accordance with research on MTurk data quality, participants who meet our inclusion criteria will have at least a 95% HIT approval rating on MTurk, and have completed at least 100 HITs (Peer, Vosgerau, and Acquisti, 2014). Participants must be located in the United States.
Participants will be recruited using Amazon’s Mechanical Turk Platform, https://www.mturk.com/, and will complete an online survey made with Qualtrics.
To facilitate a direct comparison with the results from study 1, we aim to collect data from at least 209 participants.
We will continue collecting data until we reach our planned sample size of 209 participants after exclusions.

attributes.title: Early versus Late Tracheostomy in Patients with Acute Spinal Cord Injury: A Systematic Review

q1.value: Early versus Late Tracheostomy in Patients with Acute Spinal Cord Injury: A Systematic Review

q3.value:
Tracheostomy is a common procedure done in the intensive care unit (ICU) and is often employed when patients need prolonged mechanical ventilation, which includes those with acute traumatic spinal cord injuries. More specifically, patients with a higher spinal cord injury more often require tracheostomy to manage their airway. The optimal timing for tracheostomy, however, remains unknown in patients with a spinal cord injury. This review aims to determine the optimal timing of tracheostomy and evaluate potential subsequent beneficial effects by comparing early versus late tracheostomy in patients with spinal cord injury. 

Research Questions:
Is hospital mortality lower in patients receiving an early tracheostomy compared to late tracheostomy in patients with acutely traumatic spinal cord injury?
Is ICU mortality lower in patients receiving an early tracheostomy compared to late tracheostomy in patients with acutely traumatic spinal cord injury?
Is early tracheostomy associated with any benefits in terms of hospital or ICU length of stay, duration of mechanical ventilation or duration of sedation?
Is the incidence of ventilator associated pneumonia lower in patients receiving early tracheostomy versus those patients receiving late tracheostomy? 
Are their differences in the rates of complications between early and late tracheostomy in patients with acutely traumatic spinal cord injury?

q4.value:
Hypotheses:
Early tracheostomy is associated with lower mortality compared to late tracheostomy in patients with spinal cord injuries. 
Early tracheostomy is associated with shorter duration of ICU length of stay compared to late tracheostomy in patients with spinal cord injuries. 
Early tracheostomy is associated with shorter duration of mechanical ventilation compared to late tracheostomy in patients with spinal cord injuries.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We will search for articles published in the following electronic databases: Medline (Ovid), Embase, Cochrane CENTRAL, Cochrane database of Systematic Reviews and PsychINFO.  ClinicalTrials.gov and the International Clinical Trials Registry Platform will be searched for unpublished data. In addition, the reference lists of eligible studies and review articles will be hand searched to capture articles potentially missed from the original search. The search will be performed for published and unpublished articles.

Studies will be identified using the following concept areas: (“acute traumatic spinal cord injury” OR “spinal cord injury” OR “spinal cord lesion” OR “spinal injury” OR “spinal cord dysfunction”) AND (“tracheostomy” OR “tracheotomy” OR open tracheo* OR surgical tracheo* OR percutaneous tracheo* OR dilational percutaneous tracheo* OR “cricothyrotomy” OR “open cricothyrotomy” OR “surgical cricothyrotomy” OR “percutaneous cricothyrotomy”). The search will be restricted to articles published in English language. The identified citations will be imported into an EndNote database and duplicates will be removed.).

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value:
The article selection and data extraction process will be managed on Microsoft excel. Standardized data collection sheets will be made available to reviewers through excel, allowing for the same types of data collection across included studies. The data extraction will be reviewed independently by at least two reviewers before data extraction. 
All stages of review (review of titles and abstracts, review of full texts, data abstraction and assessment of quality) will be conducted by two reviewers independently of each other. The reviewers will meet to discuss the results of their critical appraisal for a final appraisal. Disagreements on the final critical appraisal will be resolved through discussion with a third reviewer. Any additional information required for data extraction and quality assessment that is not reported will be acquired by contacting the authors of selected studies. Appendix A lists and defines all variables, including primary and secondary outcomes that will be extracted for our systematic review. Additional variables may be included after the selection of studies to capture data useful for other outcomes.

q13.value: For the studies included in the final review, we will descriptively present study demographics and additional variables, including primary and secondary outcomes in a tabular format to allow for easy comparison. Additional tables will be synthesized to present study quality assessment/risk of bias. Meta-analysis will be conducted if there will be an adequate number of studies.

question.value:
The following variables/outcomes will be measured:
Primary outcome:
1.	ICU and/or hospital mortality (early or late or total),
2.	ICU and/or hospital LOS, and 
3.	pneumonia rates

Secondary outcomes:
1.	Hospitalization costs, 
2.	Duration of sedation, and 
3.	Duration of mechanical ventilation
4.	Complications

Meta-analysis will be performed to identify differences in primary and secondary outcomes (e.g. mortality rates, pneumonia rates, duration of ICU length of stay and mechanical ventilation) in patients with acute traumatic SCI requiring an early or late tracheostomy. The random effects model by DerSimonian and Laird will be used to calculate the pooled effect sizes using R software (The R Foundation for Statistical Computing 2019). For pooled dichotomous effect measures, odds ratio (OR) with 95% confidence interval (CI) will be calculated. For pooled continuous effect measures, mean differences (MD) will be calculated. A p-value of < 0.05 will be considered statistically significant. Heterogeneity between studies will be assessed using I2 statistics.
A subgroup analysis of studies with patients undergoing early and late tracheostomy at different cut off timings will be assessed. Stratified analysis will also be performed to assess the following predictors of early tracheostomy: level of spinal injury and cervical versus thoracic spinal injuries.

attributes.title: The impact of sitting vs. standing on the rate of alcohol consumption: a pilot study
attributes.description: The aim of this pilot and feasibility study is to inform the design of a larger randomised controlled trial (RCT) to estimate the impact of drinking position (sitting vs. standing) on the rate of alcohol consumption and to determine whether it is moderated by the availability of a table. The primary aim is to inform the sample size of a larger RCT by measuring total drinking times of alcoholic beverages in four conditions. The secondary aim is to assess the feasibility of the study and the fidelity to protocol.

attributes.title: Foreign Language Effect in Public Goods Games
attributes.description: The research question will be answered using an online one-shot public goods game. A subject pool of Finnish nationals will participate in the experiment, either in Finnish or in the treatment language of English. This experiment will also include a conditional contribution chart and a question about expectations.

q1.value: Foreign Language Effect in Public Goods Games: Disentangling Cultural Context from Enhanced Deliberation and Reduced Emotionality

q3.value: There is evidence that using a foreign language affects economic behavior, studied as the Foreign Language Effect. I will conduct an online one-shot public goods game in order to see whether there is a foreign language effect for Finnish natives using English, and to disentangle any possible foreign language effect from the effect of cultural context. The control version will be in Finnish, and the treatment will be the use of English.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: The use of a foreign language (English) will cause participants to carefully deliberate about their decision and contribute less to the group. 
Hypothesis 2: The use of native language (Finnish) elicits increased emotional connection to public goods which are used and benefited from in a native language context. Thus, the use of a foreign language (English) will have less of an emotional connection for Finnish participants and cause them to contribute less to the group.
Hypothesis 3: The use of a foreign language (English) will cause participants to think less about the cultural context and have lower expectation of the contributions of other players in their group.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: Regarding above: Subjects will know which treatment they have been assigned, English or Finnish, but will not necessarily know which treatments exist.

question.value:
Subjects are randomly assigned to groups of 4. They are given 20 points which they can decide to keep for themselves or put into the group fund. They payoff for each player is: Payoff = 20 - your contribution + 1.5 [(sum of contributions from all group members)/4].

The experiment runs through the following steps:
1)There are four control questions to make sure participants understand the payoff function. They must answer these correctly to proceed, but they have as many tries as they like. 
2) Subjects proceed to state their contribution to the group (out of their endowment of 20). 
3) Following that there is a conditional contribution chart where they state what they would contribute conditional on the average contribution of other players in their group for values 0-20. 
4) After this there is a question regarding their expectations of average group contribution. 5) Lastly, participants are asked 4 follow-up questions to double check their understanding of the payoff equation.

q9.value: The online experiment has an iterative function which assigns every other participant to Finnish or English.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value:
Demographic Data has been collected, but has not been analyzed and will not have any impact on which treatment the participant receives. 

The Demographic data recorded includes citizenship, student status, contact information, place of birth, parental origin, age, gender, mother tongue, language ability in English, Finnish, Swedish, age when began learning English, living in an English speaking country, university, years of study, major

question.value: The demographic data has been collected through a survey. Those who fit the criteria for the experiment are then sent an individual link to the experiment, which will connect their demographic data to their input in the experiment. All data from the experiment and time spent on each page is collected by the experiment (using otree). The population I am collecting my subjects from are Finnish nationals who are also studying at a post-secondary institution (university or university of applied sciences). The demographic survey began in early November, the experiment will run from late January to early February 2020. The experiment will run approximately two weeks, but longer if further subjects are needed. Recruitment has been completed mainly through social media channels or through professors at Hanken School of Economics.  Two individuals will be selected at random to be paid their earnings from the experiment.

q13.value: The sample size depends on interest in participation, but ideally 50-100 people. Currently 30+ have been recruited and completed the demographic survey, but more recruitment efforts will be carried out in order to reach the target sample.

q14.value: This research is limited by time constraints due to the thesis deadline. It is also limited by financial constraints, since participants on the whole are not being paid, and that may make it difficult to find willing participants.

q15.value: Data collection procedures give full control over the exact sample size. Collection will conclude determined due to timing constraints and data collected according to the sample size goals.

question.value: The variable which is manipulated is language. Subjects either conduct the experiment in Finnish (control) or English (treatment).

Contribution: Subject's willing contribution to the group fund.

Time spent on the contribution page: using time as a proxy measure for deliberation.

Conditional Contribution: Subjects' willing contribution conditional on the average contribution of other group members (for values 0-20)

Expectation: The amount subjects' expect other group members to contribute on average. This is used as a proxy for cultural context dependent behavior.

Follow-up questions: Four values of true/false which indicate whether the participants understood the payoff formula at the end of the experiment. There will be an overall dummy variable for those who got all four questions correct.

Foreign Language: A dummy variable indicating that the subject was in the treatment group. 

Additional control variables: Those variables gathered from the pre-experiment demographic survey (citizenship, student status, contact information, place of birth, parental origin, age, gender, mother tongue, language ability in English, Finnish, Swedish, age when began learning English, living in an English speaking country, university, years of study, major). 

Contributor type: Subjects will be classified as a Positive Contributor, Conditional Contributor, Free-rider, or other based on their responses. More information in the analysis plan.

A logistic regression will be done to test the extent to which the language affects participants behavioral patterns (ex. conditionally contributing or free riding). 

An OLS regression will be done to measure the level of contribution (0-20). 
From the OLS regression a model will be estimated for decomposing the Foreign Language Effect.

Both the logistic and OLS analysis will include the following controls: gender, mother tongue, living in an English speaking country,  years of study, contributor type (free-rider, positive/conditional contributor, other). There will also be a control for those who fail the follow-up questions, indicating they did not understand the payoff function in the experiment.

q20.value:
Each participant will be coded as a Positive Contributor (contribution greater than 1) or Free-rider (contribution = 0) for the unconditional contribution section of the experiment. 
Each participant will be coded as a Conditional Contributor (contributes more relative to more contribution to others), a Free-rider (consistently contributes 0) or an other (for those contributions which follow no pattern or decrease as group contributions increase).

q21.value: P-value levels of .001, .01, and .05 will be used to determine significance. The analyses of summary statistics will be done using two-tailed tests.

q22.value: It will be verified that each subject has answered all of the questions and all of the demographic questions. Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q23.value: Any subject who has not completed the experiment and has missing data must be omitted for full analysis of the results.

q24.value: Exploratory analysis will be done by playing with additional controls received from demographic survey: place of birth, parental origin, age, language ability in English, Finnish, Swedish, age when began learning English, and major

q25.value:
Analysis is based on the following work:

registration_responses.q1: Foreign Language Effect in Public Goods Games: Disentangling Cultural Context from Enhanced Deliberation and Reduced Emotionality
registration_responses.q3: There is evidence that using a foreign language affects economic behavior, studied as the Foreign Language Effect. I will conduct an online one-shot public goods game in order to see whether there is a foreign language effect for Finnish natives using English, and to disentangle any possible foreign language effect from the effect of cultural context. The control version will be in Finnish, and the treatment will be the use of English.
registration_responses.q4:
Hypothesis 1: The use of a foreign language (English) will cause participants to carefully deliberate about their decision and contribute less to the group. 
Hypothesis 2: The use of native language (Finnish) elicits increased emotional connection to public goods which are used and benefited from in a native language context. Thus, the use of a foreign language (English) will have less of an emotional connection for Finnish participants and cause them to contribute less to the group.
Hypothesis 3: The use of a foreign language (English) will cause participants to think less about the cultural context and have lower expectation of the contributions of other players in their group.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q7: Regarding above: Subjects will know which treatment they have been assigned, English or Finnish, but will not necessarily know which treatments exist.
registration_responses.q9: The online experiment has an iterative function which assigns every other participant to Finnish or English.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11:
Demographic Data has been collected, but has not been analyzed and will not have any impact on which treatment the participant receives. 

The Demographic data recorded includes citizenship, student status, contact information, place of birth, parental origin, age, gender, mother tongue, language ability in English, Finnish, Swedish, age when began learning English, living in an English speaking country, university, years of study, major
registration_responses.q13: The sample size depends on interest in participation, but ideally 50-100 people. Currently 30+ have been recruited and completed the demographic survey, but more recruitment efforts will be carried out in order to reach the target sample.
registration_responses.q14: This research is limited by time constraints due to the thesis deadline. It is also limited by financial constraints, since participants on the whole are not being paid, and that may make it difficult to find willing participants.
registration_responses.q15: Data collection procedures give full control over the exact sample size. Collection will conclude determined due to timing constraints and data collected according to the sample size goals.
registration_responses.q20:
Each participant will be coded as a Positive Contributor (contribution greater than 1) or Free-rider (contribution = 0) for the unconditional contribution section of the experiment. 
Each participant will be coded as a Conditional Contributor (contributes more relative to more contribution to others), a Free-rider (consistently contributes 0) or an other (for those contributions which follow no pattern or decrease as group contributions increase).
registration_responses.q21: P-value levels of .001, .01, and .05 will be used to determine significance. The analyses of summary statistics will be done using two-tailed tests.
registration_responses.q22: It will be verified that each subject has answered all of the questions and all of the demographic questions. Outliers will be included in the analysis.
registration_responses.q23: Any subject who has not completed the experiment and has missing data must be omitted for full analysis of the results.
registration_responses.q24: Exploratory analysis will be done by playing with additional controls received from demographic survey: place of birth, parental origin, age, language ability in English, Finnish, Swedish, age when began learning English, and major

registration_responses.q8.question:
Subjects are randomly assigned to groups of 4. They are given 20 points which they can decide to keep for themselves or put into the group fund. They payoff for each player is: Payoff = 20 - your contribution + 1.5 [(sum of contributions from all group members)/4].

The experiment runs through the following steps:
1)There are four control questions to make sure participants understand the payoff function. They must answer these correctly to proceed, but they have as many tries as they like. 
2) Subjects proceed to state their contribution to the group (out of their endowment of 20). 
3) Following that there is a conditional contribution chart where they state what they would contribute conditional on the average contribution of other players in their group for values 0-20. 
4) After this there is a question regarding their expectations of average group contribution. 5) Lastly, participants are asked 4 follow-up questions to double check their understanding of the payoff equation.
registration_responses.q12.question: The demographic data has been collected through a survey. Those who fit the criteria for the experiment are then sent an individual link to the experiment, which will connect their demographic data to their input in the experiment. All data from the experiment and time spent on each page is collected by the experiment (using otree). The population I am collecting my subjects from are Finnish nationals who are also studying at a post-secondary institution (university or university of applied sciences). The demographic survey began in early November, the experiment will run from late January to early February 2020. The experiment will run approximately two weeks, but longer if further subjects are needed. Recruitment has been completed mainly through social media channels or through professors at Hanken School of Economics.  Two individuals will be selected at random to be paid their earnings from the experiment.
registration_responses.q16.question: The variable which is manipulated is language. Subjects either conduct the experiment in Finnish (control) or English (treatment).
registration_responses.q17.question:
Contribution: Subject's willing contribution to the group fund.

Time spent on the contribution page: using time as a proxy measure for deliberation.

Conditional Contribution: Subjects' willing contribution conditional on the average contribution of other group members (for values 0-20)

Expectation: The amount subjects' expect other group members to contribute on average. This is used as a proxy for cultural context dependent behavior.

Follow-up questions: Four values of true/false which indicate whether the participants understood the payoff formula at the end of the experiment. There will be an overall dummy variable for those who got all four questions correct.

Foreign Language: A dummy variable indicating that the subject was in the treatment group. 

Additional control variables: Those variables gathered from the pre-experiment demographic survey (citizenship, student status, contact information, place of birth, parental origin, age, gender, mother tongue, language ability in English, Finnish, Swedish, age when began learning English, living in an English speaking country, university, years of study, major). 

Contributor type: Subjects will be classified as a Positive Contributor, Conditional Contributor, Free-rider, or other based on their responses. More information in the analysis plan.
registration_responses.q19.question:
A logistic regression will be done to test the extent to which the language affects participants behavioral patterns (ex. conditionally contributing or free riding). 

An OLS regression will be done to measure the level of contribution (0-20). 
From the OLS regression a model will be estimated for decomposing the Foreign Language Effect.

Both the logistic and OLS analysis will include the following controls: gender, mother tongue, living in an English speaking country,  years of study, contributor type (free-rider, positive/conditional contributor, other). There will also be a control for those who fail the follow-up questions, indicating they did not understand the payoff function in the experiment.
